title: 111_s1726
content: The Act is titled the "USA PATRIOT Reauthorization and Additional Weapons Against Terrorism Act of 2009" and includes a table of contents outlining various sections such as the USA PATRIOT Reauthorization Act and the Classified Information Procedures Reform Act. The "Additional Government Weapons Against Terrorism Act" includes provisions for preventing material support for terrorist activities, prohibiting false travel documents, and preventing the release of convicted terrorists and sex offenders pending sentencing or appeal. The "USA PATRIOT Reauthorization Act of 2009" repeals sunset provisions from the USA PATRIOT Improvement and Reauthorization Act of 2005 and the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004. The "Classified Information Procedures Reform Act of 2009" defines key terms. The Classified Information Procedures Act is amended to define 'Disclosure' as the release of classified information to individuals during discovery or at any proceeding, excluding disclosure to an attorney with necessary security clearance. The Classified Information Procedures Act is amended to require additional authorization for receiving sensitive compartmented information or special access program information. Additionally, a technical amendment is made to the Immigration and Nationality Act. SEC. 203. Ex parte authorizations under the Classified Information Procedures Act. Section 4 of the Classified Information Procedures Act (18 U.S.C. App.) is amended to require authorization in the form of a statement made ex parte and to be considered. The court may grant relief based on this showing, including the transcript of any argument and summary of the classified information sought by the defendant. The defendant seeks to obtain the text of the statement of the United States. SEC. 204. APPLICATION OF CLASSIFIED INFORMATION PROCEDURES ACT TO NONDOCUMENTARY INFORMATION. Section 4 of the Classified Information Procedures Act is amended to include access to other classified information. If a defendant seeks access to classified information from a potential witness, they must notify the attorney for the United States and the district court in writing, specifying the information sought and the legal basis for access. The defendant may seek access to classified information, and the United States can oppose it. If the court determines the defendant is entitled to access the information, the United States can request a summary or admission of relevant facts. The United States can object or request a substitution ex parte. The defendant may seek access to classified information, and the United States can oppose it. The court may grant the United States' request to substitute a summary or admission of relevant facts if it provides the defendant with the ability to make a defense. Access to classified information is restricted to the provisions outlined in this subsection. The defendant's request for access to classified information may be discontinued or limited to non-classified lines of inquiry if not previously authorized by a court. SEC. 205 amends the Classified Information Procedures Act to allow the United States to appeal orders without regard to the Act. TITLE III is the "Additional Government Weapons Against Terrorism Act of 2009" focusing on preventing material support for terrorist suicide bombings. Chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new section, Sec. 2339E, which defines terms related to providing material support to international terrorism and prohibits such actions. Providing material support to international terrorism is prohibited under section 2339E of title 18, United States Code. Those who provide material support with the intent to facilitate terrorism can face fines, imprisonment up to 15 years, or both. If death results from the act, the offender can be imprisoned for life. The jurisdictional bases for this offense include affecting interstate or foreign commerce, using the mails or facilities of interstate or foreign commerce, and intending to facilitate terrorism. An offender can face penalties for intending to facilitate, reward, or encourage acts of international terrorism that affect interstate or foreign commerce, violate US laws, influence US government policy, or affect a foreign government's conduct within the US. An offender can face penalties for intending to facilitate, reward, or encourage acts of international terrorism that cause death or serious injury to US nationals abroad, or damage US property overseas, or influence the policy of a foreign government. The text discusses penalties for individuals involved in acts of international terrorism that result in harm to US nationals or property abroad, or aim to influence foreign government policies. Amendments are made to the table of sections in chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code. The text discusses amendments to penalize individuals involved in international terrorism, including receiving military training and providing material support to terrorist organizations. It also prohibits attempts and conspiracies to obtain military training from foreign terrorist organizations and the use of false travel documents. Amendments to Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code, include adding "false travel documents" to the list of prohibited items. This covers false identification documents, false travel documents, and penalties for their use in relation to international terrorism. Amendments to Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code, now include "false travel documents" alongside false identification documents as prohibited items. Amendments to Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code, now include "false travel documents" as prohibited items, defined as documents intended for passage on commercial aircraft or mass transportation not issued by the appropriate authority. Amendments to Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code now include "false travel documents" as prohibited items, defined as documents issued by a commercial airline or mass transportation provider or altered for deceitful purposes. Additionally, the table of sections for chapter 47 of title 18, United States Code is updated to reflect this change. SEC. 305 aims to prevent the unwarranted release of convicted terrorists and sex offenders pending sentencing or appeal. The amendment to Section 3145 of title 18, United States Code, prohibits release based on exceptional reasons for individuals detained pending sentencing or appeal in cases involving specific offenses, including those related to terrorism or crimes against minors.
